ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was great at introducing students to ecology and principles of wildlife biology.
Basic lab skills, and a broad idea of how evolution connects life on Earth.
I learned a great deal about the various diversity of life on this planet. The hands-on nature helps build an understanding and appreciation for life that a lecture course simply cannot.
We learned broadly about the biodiversity on earth and the different morphological characteristics that organisms have evolved over time.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was wonderful. It really allows students to be immersed with nature and understand the course material. The lab times were insightful and very entertaining.
Excellent labs! Always super fun and accessible, even for someone not in E&EB.
I thought the course was well organized but the grading time frame was poor. By mid-semester, only one assignment had been graded.

The course is very cool  the hands on labs are awesome and the teaching staff is super nice and generous. However, there is a fair bit of work involved, including challenging quizzes every week and several long lab reports that take at least several hours to complete.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)

Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Definitely take this course. Professor Wells is amazing and this is by far one of my favorite courses at Yale.
Yes! If you need a lab credit, or a half credit to fill in a gap, this is an amazing lab that can be taken non-concurrently with another science course.
Yes, this is a really fun and engaging lab course that I would recommend to any student who enjoyed taking BIOL104 or any evolutionary biology class.
This is NOT a gut, it ended up being a lot more work than some of my single-credit courses. Very interesting material, but a lot a work.
Yes, Marta is a wonderful professor!
This is a great course especially for people who are interested in biodiversity and ecology. Prof. Wells is a gem and the labs are fun, however the course is not as easy as you might expect.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
